questions.question: Question 1: Addison's disease is commonly associated with
questions.explanation:
Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison’s disease, is most commonly caused by 
autoimmune adrenalitis. Tuberculous adrenalitis is still a frequent cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in developing 
countries like India. It is characterized by the loss of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and 
adrenal androgen secretion. Glucocorticoid deficiency results in fatigue, lack of energy, weight loss, fever, myalgia, 
normochromic anemia, and hypoglycemia. Mineralocorticoid deficiency is characterized by 
nausea, vomiting, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, salt craving, hyponatremia, and 
hyperkalemia. Adrenal androgen deficiency manifests as a lack of energy, dry itchy skin, loss of 
libido, and loss of axillary and pubic hair (in women). Hyperpigmentation is seen in primary adrenal insufficiency due to excess 
proopiomelanocortin-derived peptides. Hyperpigmentation is not seen in secondary adrenal 
insufficiency. The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test (cortisol level 
<450-500nmol/L sampled 30 to 60 minutes after ACTH stimulation is diagnostic of adrenal 
insufficiency). Plasma ACTH, plasma renin, and serum aldosterone can help differentiate primary 
from secondary causes. Primary adrenal insufficiency will show elevated ACTH and a 
compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body. In secondary 
adrenal insufficiency, ACTH is low with normal renin and aldosterone. Treatment includes glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and adrenal androgen replacement. Other options: 159 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Patients with adrenocortical carcinoma present with features of glucocorticoid and 
adrenal androgen excess, and not adrenal insufficiency. Options C and D: Hypernephroma and medullary carcinoma thyroid are not associated with 
Addison's disease.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of adrenal insufficiency in India?
questions.explanation:
Tuberculosis is the most common cause of adrenal insufficiency in India and other developing 
countries. Idiopathic atrophy due to autoimmune conditions is the most common cause 
in developed countries.

questions.question:
Question 3: In a patient with reduced cortisol and elevated ACTH, which of the following would not be 
part of your differential diagnoses?
questions.explanation:
Elevated ACTH and reduced cortisol levels are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency. It is not a 
feature of MEN 4 syndrome. The following syndromes are associated with primary adrenal insufficiency: • Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 1 • Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 2 • Triple-A syndrome • Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome • Kearns-Sayre syndrome • IMAGe syndrome

questions.question:
Question 4: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and was started on 
levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain and 
dizziness. The left and right images below show her current appearance and her appearance 
last month, respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition? 154 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history 
of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a 
feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients. Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of 
glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most 
commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in 
these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature 
ovarian failure. Clinical features of Addison’s disease: 160

questions.question:
Question 5: What is the most common biochemical abnormality seen at presentation in patients with 
adrenal insufficiency?
questions.explanation:
Hyponatremia is the most common biochemical abnormality seen at presentation in patients with 
adrenal insufficiency. It is observed in 80% of the patients at presentation. Hyponatremia is caused by: • Mineralocorticoid deficiency • Diminished inhibition of ADH release by cortisol, resulting in mild SIADH during secondary 
adrenal insufficiency Hyperkalemia is diagnosed in 40% of the patients during initial diagnosis.

Question 6: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and 
diarrhea for the past 3 days. She has been excessively tired and dizzy for the past 2 weeks. On 
examination, there are patches of hyperpigmented skin. Blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg and 
blood glucose is 50 mg/dl. How will you confirm the diagnosis?

options.b: Serum Na+, K+, saline suppression test

questions.explanation:
161 
Sold by @itachibot This clinical scenario is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency. The confirmatory test for diagnosis is 
the ACTH stimulation test or short cosyntropin stimulation test. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are seen. Plasma levels of ACTH, renin and aldosterone are used 
to differentiate between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 20-year-old woman is being evaluated for adrenal insufficiency. You decide to check her 
serum levels of ACTH, renin, and aldosterone. Which of the following laboratory findings 
would prompt you to subsequently order a pituitary MRI?

options.a: High renin and low aldosterone levels
options.c: Low renin and high aldosterone levels

questions.explanation:
Pituitary MRI is indicated in secondary adrenal insufficiency which presents with the following 
parameters: • Low-normal ACTH level • Normal renin level • Normal aldosterone level The following findings are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency: • High ACTH levels • High renin • Low aldosterone levels Pituitary MRIs are not required in primary adrenal insufficiency. The fact that a pituitary MRI is 
done itself gives a hint towards secondary adrenal insufficiency. 162 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found 
to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on 
treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten to pack his medication for the 
trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this 
patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice. However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the 
treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and 
would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol 
assays. Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic 
strategies: • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring. • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the 
maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h. • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced 
to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who presented with an adrenal crisis is undergoing treatment with dexamethasone. 
Which of the following abnormalities will not improve with this treatment?
questions.explanation:
Hyperkalemia will not improve following administration of dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is a 
long-acting steroid with glucocorticoid action. It has no effect on hyperkalemia, which is mediated 
by mineralocorticoids. Hyponatremia is chiefly due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, however, hypocortisolism causes 
hyponatremia due to loss of feedback inhibition of ADH resulting in SIADH (syndrome of 
inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion). 163 
Sold by @itachibot Hypocortisolism can also cause postural hypotension as cortisol regulates vascular tone by 
potentiating the effects of vasoconstrictors. Thus on administration dexamethasone hyponatremia 
and postural hypotension will improve as dexamethasone has glucocorticoid action but 
hyperkalemia will not improve. Dexamethasone is used in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency as it does not 
interfere with serum cortisol measurement. Hormone

Question 10: 156 
Sold by @itachibot A 62-year-old woman who was diagnosed with a non-functioning pituitary adenoma develops 
features of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
A non-functioning pituitary adenoma causes hypopituitarism due to compression of the pituitary 
stalk. This results in secondary adrenal insufficiency. Hyperpigmentation is not a feature. This condition is characterized by an alabaster-like paleness due to the lack of ACTH secretion. In 
primary adrenal insufficiency, hyperpigmentation occurs as a result of elevated ACTH. 164 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is incorrect with respect to Addisonian pigmentation?

options.c: Does not affect the oral mucosa

questions.explanation: Addison's disease causes patchy hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa. Hyperpigmentation is also present in areas of increased friction including: • Palmar creases • Dorsal aspect of the foot • Nipples and the axillary region

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess. It causes 
primary hyperaldosteronism. Other causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are: • Conn’s syndrome – Unilateral adrenal adenoma • Glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism (< 1%) Other causes of mineralocorticoid excess are as follows: • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) • Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) • Adrenocortical carcinoma • Progesterone-induced hypertension • Cushing’s syndrome Liddle’s syndrome is due to a mutation of ENaC subunits. This results in reduced degradation of 
ENaC channels, causing prolonged mineralocorticoid action. 165 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following clinical features will you not expect to see in a patient with Conn's 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
In Conn’s syndrome, even though there is volume expansion, an underlying salt-escape 
mechanism leads to the absence of pedal edema. The volume expansion due to hypernatremia leads to right heart dilatation that stimulates the 
release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). This leads to compensatory diuresis and lack of edema 
despite sodium retention. Features of primary hyperaldosteronism: • Hypokalemia • Hypertension • Metabolic alkalosis • Polyuria (due to ANP) • Polydipsia (consequence of polyuria) • Muscle weakness

questions.question:
Question 14: 157 
Sold by @itachibot A 39-year-old man is referred for evaluation of severe hypertension that has not improved 
despite being on 3 anti-hypertensive drugs. The presence of decreased plasma renin activity 
in this patient would point to which of the following diagnoses?
questions.explanation:
Conn syndrome is a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism that presents with hypertension 
and low levels of renin. Elevated aldosterone levels cause negative feedback in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system 
(RAAS) and results in decreased renin production.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is the best initial investigation in a patient with hypokalemic 
hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Hypokalemic hypertension is suggestive of hyperaldosteronism. The screening test of choice is a 
measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone levels to calculate the aldosterone-renin ratio 
(ARR). ARR must be estimated in patients with hypertension and any one of the following features: • Drug resistance • Hypokalemia • Adrenal mass • Onset before 40 years of age Prior to the determination of ARR, hypokalemia correction must be done. If the patient is 
on spironolactone, it must be stopped 4 weeks prior to testing. Other blood pressure medication 
may be continued. ARR screen is considered positive when: • ARR > 750 pmol/L : ng/mL per hour 166 
Sold by @itachibot • Aldosterone > 450 pmol/L Option A: ACTH stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison’s disease. It presents with 
hypotension and hyperkalemia. Options B and C: If ARR is positive, CT abdomen and adrenal vein sampling are used for 
confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following tests is not performed in patients with an elevated aldosterone-renin 
ratio?
questions.explanation:
An elevated aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR) is indicative of 
primary hyperaldosteronism. Metyrapone stimulation test is used in the diagnosis of adrenal 
insufficiency, not hyperaldosteronism. A failure of suppression of aldosterone levels below 140 pmol/L indicates autonomous aldosterone 
production, which is the hallmark of primary hyperaldosteronism. This principle is used in the 
following tests: • Saline infusion test - IV administration of 2L of physiological saline over 4 hours • Oral sodium loading test - oral sodium given over 3 days • Fludrocortisone suppression test - given IV over 4 days These tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with elevated ARR, but are not 
necessary in cases of overt hypokalemic hypertension, strongly positive ARR, and high 
aldosterone. 167
